p.salute: Dear editor of the Guernica Magazine,

p.s: I am writing to you in response to the interview with Ayad Akhtar which has only recently been published in Guernica Magazine.
I read Disgraced at school and I think that faith is a big part of one's identity.
In the play Amir spits in a Jewish girlgirl's face just because his mother spat in his face for having a crush on a Jewish girl.
In scene 3 Amir spits during an Argumentargument in the face of his Jewish Friendfriend Isaac, but he doesn't even is Jewish anymore (p. 52, l. 31-33).
This shows oneon the one hand that you never can get rid of your religion but also not of your prejudices.
In my opinion you can get rid of your faith but not of the cultural habits that lead to a religion.
I also think that one never can get rid of prejudices against ones.
In the Interviewinterview Ayad Akhtar says that religion is more importandimportant than what country you come from, but in my opinion it is the other way around.
For me Religionreligion is something you can hide very well your faith is forced inside you and influences your actions from there.
YouYour origin, on the other hand, is recognisable at first glance by external characteristics and since prejudices relate to the first image of a person, you cannot get rid of them.
I hope you can understand my point of view and found my letter interesting.
